channel.title: Recruiting talented developer
channel.description:
Hello all,
I am currently recruiting a talented programmer to join my team working on a new RSC server. We are NOT using the RSCD source. The goal of this project is to develop an architecture that can scale to thousands of players and keeping the server 100% identical to the original RSC. We absolutely have a plan developed to do this.
A little about myself. I was in the RSC scene years ago making small bots. I am now a professional programmer and am doing this work on the side. I also am going to school to complete a Computer Science degree. All of the people that are on this development team are paid to program in one way or another, and we are doing this as a fun side-project to test our skills. We all bring something different to the table, and thats what I will be looking for from the person that joins our team.
I am purposefully not leaving a lot of information here, and if you are interested in creating the future of RSC servers, please send me a PM and I will get back to you ASAP.
Thanks, Kyle

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @Vend Vend
item.description:
@Vend wrote:

Bump.

Still looking for a new developer to join us. Contact me via PM and I will give you information to come chat with the team and see if we will be a fit for each other.

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:26, topic:414777”][quote author=veer link=topic=516737.msg3753392#msg3753392 date=1316225005]
You’re right, I made a mistake in communicating what I meant.
What I really meant was that timing out for 1000 or 500ms is just plain… /unnecessary/. You take away time from checking for I/O events. In that time you could have events queue up, while with a more immediate, asynchronous model like mine you dispatch events right as they come in.
If you need to make changes in like event interests or what not, you can wake the selector up.
In a system with many players, constant timeouts could be inefficient.
[/quote]

Did you not ready why they timeout? They do it so they can go and process idle sessions. When you lose a cycle tops to do this, I wouldn’t call it /unnecessary/ Our systems require that data be sent out every 600ms. Stopping the selector for very little time will not make a difference[/quote]
Sent out indeed, but what about incoming data? You can expect a packet from every client at least once a second.
Processing idle sessions can be implemented in another way; you can schedule a time-out task in the future for something like ~100 ticks which would mean a full minute of inactivity. When a read occurs, you merely invalidate and reschedule the task. This way your networking I/O only needs to be interrupted by requests to modify selector state.

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:25, topic:414777”]You’re right, I made a mistake in communicating what I meant.
What I really meant was that timing out for 1000 or 500ms is just plain… /unnecessary/. You take away time from checking for I/O events. In that time you could have events queue up, while with a more immediate, asynchronous model like mine you dispatch events right as they come in.
If you need to make changes in like event interests or what not, you can wake the selector up.
In a system with many players, constant timeouts could be inefficient.[/quote]

Did you not ready why they timeout? They do it so they can go and process idle sessions. When you lose a cycle tops to do this, I wouldn’t call it /unnecessary/ Our systems require that data be sent out every 600ms. Stopping the selector for very little time will not make a difference

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:24, topic:414777”][quote author=veer link=topic=516737.msg3753381#msg3753381 date=1316224573]
http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/mina/trunk/core/src/main/java/org/apache/mina/transport/tcp/NioSelectorProcessor.java

https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jboss/netty/channel/socket/nio/SelectorUtil.java

Being built on-top of NIO does not mean they work in the same fashion mine does. Maybe next time you should thoroughly attempt to comprehend posts before commenting on them… it may just help!

[/quote]

That means it times out after 1second, and 500ms respectively. Not that it waits that long to check again… While it is “selecting” it is still actively looking for operations. After the set timeout, it will stop looking and handle its other logic before it comes back again. Which happens in mere milliseconds.[/quote]

You’re right, I made a mistake in communicating what I meant.
What I really meant was that timing out for 1000 or 500ms is just plain… /unnecessary/. You take away time from checking for I/O events. In that time you could have events queue up, while with a more immediate, asynchronous model like mine you dispatch events right as they come in.
If you need to make changes in like event interests or what not, you can wake the selector up.
In a system with many players, constant timeouts could be inefficient.

Read full topic

https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jboss/netty/channel/socket/nio/SelectorUtil.java

Being built on-top of NIO does not mean they work in the same fashion mine does. Maybe next time you should thoroughly attempt to comprehend posts before commenting on them… it may just help!
;)[/quote]

That means it times out after 1second, and 500ms respectively. Not that it waits that long to check again… While it is “selecting” it is still actively looking for operations. After the set timeout, it will stop looking and handle its other logic before it comes back again. Which happens in mere milliseconds.

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/mina/trunk/core/src/main/java/org/apache/mina/transport/tcp/NioSelectorProcessor.java

https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jboss/netty/channel/socket/nio/SelectorUtil.java

Being built on-top of NIO does not mean they work in the same fashion mine does. Maybe next time you should thoroughly attempt to comprehend posts before commenting on them… it may just help!

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:21, topic:414777”][quote author=IlikeArrays link=topic=516737.msg3752603#msg3752603 date=1316145744]
If you want to hold thousands of players then you should look into creating your own framework as already stated. The idea behind my project is not for a replica so I don’t see why we would need to collaborate. My side project is too replicate rsc pking with the lowest latency. RSCDEF holds that title, it has the lowest latency between server <> client communication than any other publicly released source. My project is more of a test.

If you really want to get far with rsc your gonna want to work client sided.
[/quote]

Actually, I’d bet /my/ system has lower latency. I think I may described it before, but in the case I haven’t… generally, I use NIO and invoke Selector.select() without timeout in a dedicated thread… this ensures I can handle events immediately, while frameworks like MINA and Netty prefer to not use such a blocking thread and instead check every 500ms. You really can’t pretend queuing internally isn’t just as much of a bottleneck as queuing externally, though.

http://jim-mcbeath.blogspot.com/2011/03/java-nio-and-scala-continuations.html:

If using the standard java.io package, the only option for reading from multiple streams without blocking is to poll using the available method. Besides the wasted CPU time, as the number of active clients grows the polling loop takes longer to run, meaning additional latency before the application notices that any particular stream is ready for reading and thus increased response time. The Java NIO package provides an efficient solution for this problem.

Being reactive, inverting control, and separating concerns is nearly /always/ what you want to do. Dealing with socket I/O readiness events is no exception.

On the topic of RSCDEF in general, throwing more and more threads at a problem is /seldom/ the right solution.[/quote]

MINA and Netty are built on top of NIO, and they both use a selector, just like you stated. Where the hell did you get the idea they check every 500ms?

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“IlikeArrays, post:9, topic:414777”]If you want to hold thousands of players then you should look into creating your own framework as already stated. The idea behind my project is not for a replica so I don’t see why we would need to collaborate. My side project is too replicate rsc pking with the lowest latency. RSCDEF holds that title, it has the lowest latency between server <> client communication than any other publicly released source. My project is more of a test.

If you really want to get far with rsc your gonna want to work client sided.[/quote]

Actually, I’d bet /my/ system has lower latency. I think I may described it before, but in the case I haven’t… generally, I use NIO and invoke Selector.select() without timeout in a dedicated thread… this ensures I can handle events immediately, while frameworks like MINA and Netty prefer to not use such a blocking thread and instead timeout after 500 or 1000ms. You really can’t pretend queuing internally isn’t just as much of a bottleneck as queuing externally, though.

If using the standard java.io package, the only option for reading from multiple streams without blocking is to poll using the available method. Besides the wasted CPU time, as the number of active clients grows the polling loop takes longer to run, meaning additional latency before the application notices that any particular stream is ready for reading and thus increased response time. The Java NIO package provides an efficient solution for this problem.

Being reactive, inverting control, and separating concerns is nearly /always/ what you want to do. Dealing with socket I/O readiness events is no exception.

On the topic of RSCDEF in general, throwing more and more threads at a problem is /seldom/ the right solution.

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @Vend Vend
item.description:
@Vend wrote:

[quote=“Not_a_bot, post:19, topic:414777”][quote author=Vend link=topic=516737.msg3752749#msg3752749 date=1316180797]

RSCDEF holds that title, it has the lowest latency between server <> client communication than any other publicly released source. [/quote]

Where’s your proof? Latency is entirely up to the connection speeds of the people playing.

Lol. What about the time the server spends processing the packets and sending a response? Since each client has their own thread all the processing happens concurrently. The event based model and zoning system used in RSCDEF also allows for faster processing than other servers.

They aren’t all handled concurrently though. The max in the best possible situation is the number of logical processors you have. Up to 8 on a dedicated server, and 2-4 on a desktop. All of the threads get dealt with in a round robin type system where they all share a slice of time to do their work

Yes, I’m aware. That is what concurrency is. So instead of processing each client one at a time, your processors are actively switching between multiple client threads, which is most definitely faster because you do not have to wait for an entire server loop to process the client again. The main issue with RSCDEF is it does not scale well because it is trying to process too many threads at the same time. That is where design changes come in

I can’t really see how you’ll be able to scale multiple threads if they’re not all treated in the same importance… Given that it is “faster” threading out each client, there are situations that arise that don’t absolutely warrant it (say the Player is only chatting/idling not requiring constant updates vs another Player who is fighting/eating/casting). Thus you would be losing precious processing power on minimal work loads, rather than giving everyone equal processing time.[/quote]

You are correct. Like I have said, we are NOT using the exact implementation RSCDEF provides. This is a very common problem that has plenty of solutions. One is pretty obvious and has been used in other servers.

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“Vend, post:14, topic:414777”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=516737.msg3752746#msg3752746 date=1316180195]

RSCDEF holds that title, it has the lowest latency between server <> client communication than any other publicly released source. [/quote]

Where’s your proof? Latency is entirely up to the connection speeds of the people playing.

Lol. What about the time the server spends processing the packets and sending a response? Since each client has their own thread all the processing happens concurrently. The event based model and zoning system used in RSCDEF also allows for faster processing than other servers.

They aren’t all handled concurrently though. The max in the best possible situation is the number of logical processors you have. Up to 8 on a dedicated server, and 2-4 on a desktop. All of the threads get dealt with in a round robin type system where they all share a slice of time to do their work

Yes, I’m aware. That is what concurrency is. So instead of processing each client one at a time, your processors are actively switching between multiple client threads, which is most definitely faster because you do not have to wait for an entire server loop to process the client again. The main issue with RSCDEF is it does not scale well because it is trying to process too many threads at the same time. That is where design changes come in :)[/quote]

I can’t really see how you’ll be able to scale multiple threads if they’re not all treated in the same importance… Given that it is “faster” threading out each client, there are situations that arise that don’t absolutely warrant it (say the Player is only chatting/idling not requiring constant updates vs another Player who is fighting/eating/casting). Thus you would be losing precious processing power on minimal work loads, rather than giving everyone equal processing time.

Read full topic

item.title: Recruiting talented developer
item.dc:creator: @Vend Vend
item.description:
@Vend wrote:

nacional:

cyan that dude that made the sleepers?

Yes.

Not_a_bot:

why not write your base rather than using others? It’s not that difficult. What’s the plan for improving RSCDEF?

RSCDEF is already written. It is a very solid base and with some changes it could become great. We already have implemented some very cool technologies to increase the processing speeds of our server. I am not posting any of our plans on forums right now, as we are not developing this for the community. This project is only going to be used for the server we plan on running.

If anyone is interested, send me a PM and I will give you information to come talk to the team.

Read full topic
